intro: Rhododendron dryophyllum, commonly known as the western rhododendron, is a species native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It is a deciduous shrub that typically grows in moist, well-drained soils in forested areas. The plant features showy, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink, often appearing in clusters. Its leaves are evergreen, leathery, and elliptical in shape, providing year-round foliage. Rhododendron dryophyllum is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological importance in supporting local wildlife.
